Award.AwardTitle: Diagnosing misconceptions about algebra using Bayesian inverse reinforcement learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, to be conducted by researchers at the University of California, Berkeley, and Carleton College, will develop an online math tutor to help high school and college students learn algebra. The tutor will diagnose students' misconceptions about algebra by asking them to solve a series of math problems. The website will be made available to students anywhere, making it possible to collect large amounts of data on algebra problem solving that will be used to refine the technological approach, develop computational models of student learning, optimize the design of tests, and identify effective strategies for online learning and teaching. This project will advance the work of the REAL (Research on Education and Learning) program in studying the cognitive basis of STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) learning, as well as the Cyberlearning program in discovering how to design and effectively use learning technologies of the future.

The approach used for knowledge diagnosis in the online tutor will be Bayesian inverse reinforcement learning. This approach combines ideas from machine learning and cognitive science. Students' responses will be modeled using Markov decision processes, a decision-theoretic formalism that indicates how a rational agent should take a series of actions to achieve a goal. This will make it possible to calculate the probability that a student would take a particular series of actions, given his or her knowledge of the domain. Bayesian inference will be used to invert this model, providing a probability distribution over the knowledge state of the student given his or her actions. Applying this approach to algebra problem solving will make it possible to identify students' misconceptions from freeform solutions to algebra problems. The proposed research will require addressing challenges such as working with the infinite, structured state spaces that are needed to describe algebraic equations, accommodating composite actions (such as skipping a step in a derivation), modeling learning, and optimizing the design of assessments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mastery of algebra is important for many different career and educational paths, but students may be hindered in attaining mastery of algebra by gaps in their knowledge or systematic misunderstandings about the rules of algebra. In this project, we developed automated algorithms that examine the way that people solve algebraic equations to make individual assessments about their strategies and misunderstandings. The algorithms that we developed assume that people solve equations in ways that they believe are correct, but that there are a variety of systematic ways that people may misunderstand both the rules of algebra as well as how to sequence their equation solving to get to a solution. These algorithms are particular suited for situations where people must take multiple steps to solve problems or achieve a goal, and some or all of those steps may be difficult to evaluate individually as correct or incorrect. For example, different equation solving steps may be mathematically correct, but be relevant for different strategies; in isolation, it may not be possible to identify the correctness of a single step. We designed these algorithms to interpret people's equation solving with or without step-by-step correction, with the goal of enabling people of varying ability levels to demonstrate what they do know. While developing these algorithms we also developed a website, Emmy's Workshop (emmysworkshop.com), to both enable the broader public to benefit from these individualized assessments and collect data about problem solving for the development and iterative improvement of the algorithms.

In this project, we showed that the algorithms we developed were able to accurately interpret people's equation solving and that its assessments were generally consistent with teacher's assessments.  We also showed that for learners who struggle with some parts of equation solving but not with others, choosing a tutorial based on the algorithm's assessment of their strengths and weaknesses rather than random tutorial results in increased learning. This is important because it illustrates that the assessments are not only accurate, but pedagogically meaningful for helping learners.

One of the challenges of the algorithm that we developed is that it requires specific knowledge about an educational domain. For instance, in the case of equation solving, it requires a model for what principles of equation solving people might misunderstand and what possible ways they might misunderstand these principles. Our work developed a way to take a common representation for these types of models and convert it into the form required for our algorithm. This is likely to make it easier to make fine-grained assessments of people's understanding based on their actions in interactive problem solving or games in a variety of different educational domains.

The project also developed models for making sense of people's estimates of their own skills, and through behavioral experiments, we found that people were more accurate at assessing their own ability in domains like algebra compared to domains like trivia that are commonly used in experiments about these types of estimates. These models also allowed us to examine how people's assessments of their abilities changed over time. This type of work is important for identifying what factors influence people's estimates, a precursor for helping people improve their estimates. Such estimates are likely of increasing importance as online learning becomes more common and learners must make choices about what material to spend time focusing on.

A final outcome of the project was significant training for both graduate and undergraduate students, with a particular emphasis on undergraduate research. Thirteen undergraduates at a small liberal arts college received research training through the project. The interdisciplinary nature of the project gave students training in computer science, cognitive science, and education, and students learned to apply new computational and machine learning skills to educational data. The applied nature of the project broadened their understanding of the ethical considerations in educational data science.
